channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Where a Taboo Is Leading to the Deaths of Young Girls
item.media:description: In parts of western Nepal, woman are banished to chhaupadi huts like this one in the village of Pali when they get their periods.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: In western Nepal, women are banished from their homes every month when they get their periods. They are considered polluted, and many die as a result.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: On Mexico’s Migrant Trail: Trump Policy Means Tough Choices
item.media:description: Migrants using handmade rafts crossed the river that separates Guatemala from Mexico on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.description: As word of the Trump administration’s “zero tolerance” policy reaches migrants, some reconsider their trips but others press on.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Vote in Canada Paves the Way for Legalization of Marijuana
item.media:description: Canadians celebrated National Marijuana Day in Ottawa in April 2016. On Tuesday, Canada’s Senate voted to legalize marijuana for recreational use, though Canadians will not be able to buy it legally for a few more months.
item.description: Now that lawmakers in both houses have voted to legalize marijuana for recreational use, the government will give Canada’s provinces a few months to prepare for the law’s rollout.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Violence in Nicaragua Undermines Peace Talks 2 Months Into Uprising
item.media:description: Protesters using homemade weapons during clashes with the police in Masaya, Nicaragua, on Tuesday. At least four people died and more than 30 were injured during the day of fighting.
item.description: President Daniel Ortega’s government is continuing its bloody crackdown on opponents, dimming hopes for a negotiated settlement.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Merkel and Macron Try to Save European Union, and Themselves
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Emmanuel Macron of France discussed at a meeting Tuesday how to put out the growing number of populist fires over migration on the Continent.
item.description: Meeting before a key European summit meeting, the French and German leaders found compromises on the euro and a reform of migration policies.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: The Five Conflicts Driving the Bulk of the World’s Refugee Crisis
item.media:description: Syrian asylum seekers outside their tent at a makeshift camp near the military-run Moria camp, in Lesbos, Greece.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Most of the world’s refugees are from five countries, according to the U.N. refugee agency. Here is a look at the conflicts driving the global refugee crisis.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United Nations High Commission for Refugees

item.title: Eritrea to Send Delegation to Ethiopia for Peace Talks
item.media:description: President Isaias Afwerki of Eritrea in 2011. He has ruled the country since it gained independence from Ethiopia in 1993.
item.description: Eritrea, one of the world’s most closed-off nations, made the announcement after Ethiopia said it would fully accept the terms of 2000 peace accord.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Italian Minister Moves to Count and Expel Roma, Drawing Outrage
item.media:description: “And Italian Roma? Unfortunately we have to keep them,” Italy’s new interior minister, Matteo Salvini, said on Monday during an interview on a regional television station.
item.description: Interior Minister Matteo Salvini called for a census of Roma people, to deport those without legal status, angering allies and evoking memories of fascist racial laws.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: As Auto Industry Transforms, Ford and Volkswagen Consider an Alliance
item.media:description: Volkswagen and Ford, two of the world’s biggest carmakers, are looking to join forces on projects like the development of commercial vehicles.
item.description: The two companies said they were exploring a strategic partnership, looking to join forces on projects like the development of commercial vehicles.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Australia Diary: When Texans Try Vegemite
item.description: We couldn’t help it — an Australia Diary taste test for Australia’s favorite* food.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: As Greece Ends a Decade of Bailouts, Problems Linger for Europe
item.media:description: Marching on the Greek parliament in Athens to protest the government’s labor reforms. European Union officials are expected to unveil a plan in Brussels on Thursday to get the indebted country to stand on its own.
item.description: European officials are eager to paint Greece as a comeback story. But troubles in nearby Italy show that the euro’s issues have not been laid to rest.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Australia’s Anxiety About World Affairs
item.description: A new poll finds that Australians are disillusioned with President Trump, and worried about Chinese investment, immigration and climate change.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Child Separations, Tariffs, U.N.: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: That’s ‘Mr. President’ to You: Macron Scolds French Student
item.description: Emmanuel Macron used a superior tone to instruct a junior high student, just as he has with union members, older citizens and the unemployed.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Do You Know Where Your Pride T-Shirt Was Made?
item.media:description: A sequined cap from Primark and a pride tank top from Target.
item.description: Merchandise for L.G.B.T. celebrations is becoming big business for major retailers, but some products are made in countries where gay people are persecuted.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: Battle Intensifies for Yemeni Port as Dock Workers Still Unload Aid
item.media:description: Yemeni pro-government forces in the area around Al Hudaydah’s airport last week.
item.description: Three ships with enough aid to feed six million people for a month were unloaded in Al Hudaydah, even as fighting around the Yemeni port raged.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED ALI KALFOOD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Amid Border Controversy, State Department Draws Fire for Facebook Travel Tips
item.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol agents talking to a group of Central American asylum seekers before taking them into custody near McAllen, Texas, last week.
item.description: It may not have been the most opportune time for the State Department to offer family travel tips. The responses spoke volumes.
item.dc:creator: SATOSHI SUGIYAMA

item.title: Stung by a Boy’s Suffering, U.K. Reviews Medical Marijuana Rules
item.media:description: Billy Caldwell with his mother, Charlotte. The boy suffers epileptic seizures that can last for hours.
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The rethink was ordered after a 12-year-old’s cannabis-based epilepsy medicine was confiscated, eventually landing him in a hospital with severe seizures.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Kashmir Government in Turmoil as Coalition Breaks Down
item.media:description: Protesters and Indian security forces clashed in Srinagar, Kashmir, over the weekend.
item.description: With security in the region deteriorating, India’s governing party, the Hindu-nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, ended a three-year alliance with a Muslim-majority group.
item.dc:creator: SAMEER YASIR and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: U.S. Protester Held in Vietnam Confesses on State Television
item.media:description: Will Nguyen’s family said they feared his case could drag on for months.
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Mary Daniel, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Will Nguyen of Houston was grabbed and beaten by the police this month at an anti-China protest in Ho Chi Minh City.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Nonfiction: Cyberwarfare — the Latest Technology of Destruction
item.description: David E. Sanger’s “The Perfect Weapon” is an encyclopedic account of developments in the cyberworld.
item.dc:creator: PAUL R. PILLAR

item.title: Rescuers Search for More Than 160 Missing After Indonesian Ferry Sinks
item.media:description: Rescuers searched Tuesday for missing passengers in Lake Toba, on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, where a ferry sank on Monday with scores of people aboard.
item.description: The ferry sank in a lake on Sumatra island this week as Indonesians were celebrating the Eid al-Fitr holiday.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Doors for Refugees Close as Displaced Population Soars, U.N. Says
item.media:description: A group of Syrian refugee children prepared to leave Lebanon in April and return to their village southwest of Damascus, Syria. Fifty-two percent of all refugees are children younger than 18, according to the United Nations.
item.description: A refugee agency’s annual report shows no letup in the number of people who fled their homes in 2017.
item.dc:creator: SATOSHI SUGIYAMA

item.title: Kim Jong-un Returns to China, This Time With Leverage
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China welcomed North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Tuesday. Analysts said the trade conflict between China and the United States put Mr. Kim in an enviable position.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: As the United States and China drift into a trade war, Mr. Kim, a week after meeting President Trump, will have the chance to play one power against the other.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Migrants, World Cup, Apple: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB, LOUIS LUCERO II and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Napoleon’s Hat, Dropped at Waterloo, Is Picked Up at Auction for $400,000
item.media:description: Even damaged goods attract deep-pocketed buyers when associated with Napoleon. This battered hat brought over $400,000 at auction.
item.description: One of the French emperor’s iconic two-cornered military hats, said to have been left on the battlefield, soared past its presale price estimate.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Israel Charges a Former Minister With Spying for Iran
item.media:description: Gonen Segev
item.media:credit: Israeli Government Press Office, via Reuters
item.description: Iranian intelligence recruited the former minister in Africa, the Israeli authorities said. He already had a shady past as a convicted drug dealer.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: In China Trade War, Apple Worries It Will Be Collateral Damage
item.description: Caught in the trade fight between Washington and Beijing, Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has become something of an envoy while trying to protect the company’s business in China.
item.dc:creator: JACK NICAS and PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Fact Check: Trump’s False and Misleading Claims About Germany’s Crime and Immigration
item.media:description: The arrivals hall for refugees in the State Office for Refugee Affairs, in Berlin last month.
item.media:credit: Kay Nietfeld/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.description: The president suggested Chancellor Angela Merkel’s migration policy was responsible for rising crime and causing Germans to turn against their leaders.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE and MICHAEL WOLGELENTER

item.title: ‘Brexit Dividend’ for N.H.S.? British Leader Revives a Pledge
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May delivered a speech in London, on Monday promising a “Brexit dividend” for the National Health Service.
item.description: The claim that leaving the European Union would free up money for health care, a potent argument during the referendum, was long ago dismissed as bogus.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: At War: There’s Been a Global Increase in Armed Groups. Can They Be Restrained?
item.media:description: An opposition fighter in Akobo, South Sudan, in January 2018.
item.description: A rise in armed groups around the world has forced organizations to reconsider how they promote respect for humanitarian law.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH R. ROSEN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: As Trump Escalates Trade Fight, China Can Take the Hit
item.media:description: The tariffs would represent only a small burden to China’s nearly $13 trillion economy. The dispute with the United States has become a battle over which country will dominate the high-wage, high-skill industries of tomorrow, like at this electronics factory in Qingdao, China.
item.description: The trade measures President Trump is imposing will do little to hurt China’s growth, though they could add to Beijing’s problems down the road.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Australian Nun in Philippines Gets Deportation Reprieve
item.media:description: Patricia Fox, left, an Australian nun who has lived in the Philippines for many years, in Manila on Monday after winning a reprieve from a move to deport her that had the vocal support of President Rodrigo Duterte.
item.description: Justice officials say Sister Patricia Fox, 71, who was criticized for opposing Duterte administration policies, can stay for now.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Man Executed in Iran Over Officers’ Deaths at Protest
item.media:description: The funeral for one of the three police officers killed when a bus rammed into them during a protest by followers of a Sufi leader in Tehran in February.
item.description: The hanging of the man accused of driving a bus over three police officers was described as a warning to political dissidents.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Filipinos Convicted of Killing U.S. Marine in 2012 Are Captured
item.media:description: Maj. George Anikow in Afghanistan in 2009. Mr. Anikow, the husband of an American Embassy employee in the Philippines, was killed in a fight in Manila in late 2012.
item.media:credit: Sgt. Pete Thibodeau/United States Marine Corps
item.description: Two men who had avoided prison time in the death of the American major in a brawl were seized in Manila, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: As Europe’s Liberal Order Splinters, Trump Wields an Ax
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany left Parliament on Monday after a meeting with the leadership of her party.
item.media:credit: Kay Nietfeld/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany struggled Monday to hold her coalition together. President Trump seemed to take glee in his ally’s troubles.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: U.N. Rights Chief Tells U.S. to Stop Taking Migrant Children From Parents
item.media:description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, left, in Geneva on Monday. “The thought that any state would seek to deter parents by inflicting such abuse on children is unconscionable,” he said.
item.description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, cited the president of the American Association of Pediatrics, saying the practice is “government-sanctioned child abuse.”
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Audi Names Interim C.E.O. After Rupert Stadler Is Arrested
item.media:description: Mr. Stadler is the highest-ranking Volkswagen executive still in his job to have been identified as a suspect in the diesel emissions case.
item.description: Mr. Stadler, a member of Volkswagen’s management board, had been placed under formal investigation days earlier in relation to a diesel emissions scandal.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Google, Rebuilding Its Presence in China, Invests in Retailer JD.com
item.media:description: Google is investing $550 million in the Chinese online retailer JD.com. In return, the Chinese company will work with Google on e-commerce projects elsewhere in the world.
item.description: Its search engine has been blocked in the country for years, but the company is looking for other ways to be part of the flourishing internet scene there.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Are Women Responsible for Their Own Safety? Australians Point Fingers After Comedian’s Rape and Murder
item.media:description: The vigil, dubbed Reclaim Princes Park, in Melbourne, Australia, on Monday.
item.media:credit: Christina Simons for The New York Times
item.description: Mourners at vigils for Eurydice Dixon questioned police advice to women to “take responsibility” when walking alone at night.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Erdogan’s Plan to Raise a ‘Pious Generation’ Divides Parents in Turkey
item.media:description: Students at a religious high school in Istanbul. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has expanded religious schools, from 450 just 15 years ago to 4,500 today.
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.description: Seeking re-election, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan hopes to leave a lasting imprint by opening thousands of religious schools, even as standards slip in public ones.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Hopes for New Era of Malaysian Free Speech Are High, but Pending
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad came to office with a campaign agenda to roll back restrictions on free speech — though in his previous stints as Malaysia’s leader, he was not known for tolerance.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Malaysia’s new government pledged to end harsh laws restricting expression, but activists and journalists who have faced criminal charges remain wary.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Japan Earthquake Kills at Least 3 Near Osaka, Injuring Hundreds More
item.media:description: Water flooding out from a crack in the road in Takatsuki, Japan, after a 6.1-magnitude earthquake on Monday.
item.media:credit: Yohei Nishimura/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.description: The Japan Meteorological Agency said the 6.1-magnitude quake was recorded Monday morning north of Osaka.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Colombia Elects Iván Duque, a Young Populist, as President
item.media:description: Iván Duque, buoyed by a conservative upwelling in Colombia, won the presidency on Sunday.
item.description: Mr. Duque defeated a leftist rival by tapping into dissatisfaction with the economy and a contentious peace deal with rebels.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and SUSAN ABAD

item.title: 5 Dead in Texas After S.U.V. Packed With Immigrants Crashes in High-Speed Chase
item.media:description: An S.U.V. carrying 12 unauthorized immigrants in South Texas crashed after being pursued by Border Patrol agents on Sunday.
item.description: Fourteen people were packed into the vehicle, which was speeding 100 miles per hour when it rolled over, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MERVOSH

item.title: Did Mexico’s Revelry in World Cup Win Over Germany Cause an Earthquake?
item.media:description: Mexican fans gathered in Tijuana on Sunday to celebrate their country’s victory against Germany in their first 2018 men’s soccer World Cup match.
item.description: A quake was “possibly because of mass jumping” — moments after the Mexican men’s soccer team scored a goal against powerhouse Germany.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Far-Right Protesters Arrested at Kiev Gay Pride March
item.media:description: A gay pride march in Kiev, Ukraine, on Sunday took place under heavy security.
item.description: The police detained 56 members of a far-right group who attempted to disrupt the march with gas canisters.
item.dc:creator: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE
